Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear and Adaptive Acoustic Metamaterials for Novel Wave-Based Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate nonlinear acoustic metamaterials with adaptive properties for the design of next-generation wave-based devices. The necessary nonlinear interactions and adaptivity will be derived from two primary material systems: one based on controllable post-buckled lattices, and the other based on piezoelectric tunable metamaterials. The research will also exploit large deformations resulting from structural instabilities as an effective way to adapt the topology and the periodicity of a structured material. Stiffening and softening effects, amplitude-dependent dispersion, and stability will be studied in terms of their effect on the wave guiding characteristics. Fundamental understanding of nonlinear and adaptive acoustic metamaterials, and the exploration of their wave propagation behavior, will support the conception, fabrication, and experimental testing of innovative wave-based devices, to include tunable filters, waveguides, acoustic diodes, noise isolators, and directed-energy systems.

If successful, the results of this research will significantly advance knowledge and understanding in the general area of tunable and adaptive nonlinear metamaterials. This understanding will be important for the development of innovative devices for use in communication systems (mobile phones, GPS units, etc.), noise isolation, energy redirection, and acoustic filters, logic ports and switches. Advances from the research topics will be disseminated widely through academic courses on wave mechanics at Georgia Tech and in undergraduate research opportunities. Broadening of participation will be achieved by specifically working with underrepresented students through ongoing programs available at Georgia Tech. In addition, educational laboratory activities and classroom modules, developed in partnership with the GIFT program at Georgia Tech, will expose high school and middle school underrepresented students to basic results of the research and to underlying wave mechanics principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated nonlinear and adaptive (via piezoelectric coupling) acoustic metamaterials for novel wave-based devices. Metamaterials possessing single or multiple scales of periodicity exhibit advantageous wave propagation behavior to include frequency bandgaps (frequency bands in which wave propagation is prohibited), response directionality, left-handedness, and negative acoustic refraction, all of which can be employed for the design of acoustic devices operating over a broad range of frequencies and length scales. Nonlinear metamaterials exhibit further advantageous behavior, such as amplitude-dependent dispersion characteristics, which can be exploited to yield tunable classes of devices such as acoustic diodes and other logic elements whose functionality uniquely relies on nonlinear interactions among the metamaterial constituents. Application to the design of filters, waveguides, logic ports, and ultrasonic transducer arrays can, for example, be used to perform a variety of acoustics-based signal processing functions at frequencies where electronics suffer from severe power limitations. Other novel structural configurations may be exploited for acoustic super-lensing, super-focusing and/or cloaking.

The research specifically focused on predicting and verifying invariant wave propagation in one- and two-dimensional acoustic periodic structures with nonlinearity using analytical and numerical methods to predict amplitude-dependent, tunable band structure with consideration of waveform invariance and stability. In two-dimensions, the angular dependence of invariance and stability were documented for the first time together with possible devices exploiting such behavior. In a parallel effort, metamaterials were explored as a means for harvesting waves in plate-like structures. A multiple scattering method for analyzing these problems, together with experimental validation, has been developed, and a general T-matrix formulation for including the effect of the piezoelectric harvester, together with validation, has also been completed.

Several outcomes from the research have advanced the understanding of nonlinear and adaptive acoustic metamaterials, to include:

  1. A mathematical perturbation approach for calculating amplitude-dependent Lamb wave dispersion in nonlinear plates has been presented for the first time. This greatly increases our understanding of wave propagation in these nonlinear structures.
  2. Higher-order, multiple scales perturbation analyses of nonlinear monoatomic and diatomic chains and 2-D lattices have been developed which predict, for the first time, plane wave stability and invariant, multiharmonic waves of infinite extent analogous. These long-term, nonlocalized invariant plane waves have the potential for propagating coherent information over long distances, unlike single harmonic plane waves which suffer from decoherence and stability issues.  This has implications for conveying information in nonlinear materials over long distances without data loss.
  3. A multiple scattering framework for predicting wave energy harvested by a circular piezoelectric disk attached to a thin plate, and surrounded by a periodic arrangement of scatterers, has been developed for the first time. In addition, the voltage generated by the harvester can be calculated using coupled electromechanical equations.  The framework also includes a general-purpose T-matrix formulation for predicting waves scattered by a piezoelectric disk. This fast and accurate analysis makes possible the detailed study of electromechanical metamaterials, and opens possibilities for quickly exploring device designs.
